The project would pursue a two- pronged approach: (a) provision of generic support in three regions to all profitable agroprocessing private entrepreneurs, upstream and downstream of agricultural production, and (b) transfer of specialized expertise to enterprises operating in subsectors or product lines with a high potential for intemational export which require high-quality standards, such as fresh and dried fruits and vegetables, hides and skins, and shea nuts and other exotic products. Project management would be entrusted to an "Agricultural Trading and Processing Promotion Agency" a non-profit organization, to be created by the Permanent Assembly of Malian Chambers of Agriculture, who will delegate to it full authority for the implementation of this project and would ensure its full autonomy in managing it. The Government will exercise overall project supervision

The Agency will have streamlined operating structures, comprising a zoordinating unit located in Bamako, and, in full operation, three regional support units. The project will provide funding for: (i) the operation of the Agency's three regional branches in the Sikasso, Segou, and Mopti regions; (ii) support packages, including specialized technical assistance, training, studies and investment funds for three professional organizations promoting vertical integration for the fruit/vegetable, hides/skins, and oilseeds/sheanut subsectors; (iii) the Agency's operations and management, and the establishment and operation of an agricultural processing and marketing information exchange network; and (iv) activities aimed at facilitating entrepreneurs' access to investment financing and credit. Project Implementation: During the first two years, only two regional agency branches (Sikasso and Segou, which have obvious potential for agroprocessing) and one support package to a professional organization (AMELEF, for the fruit and vegetable subsector), will be launched. A mid-term review will assess the impact and performance of the first phase and make recommendations to improve project design and implementation. It will also address the question of whether to expand project support to one or more regional agency branch (Mopti) and to two more subsectoral professional organizations. Benefits: The main project benefits would be higher growth rates in the agricultural trading and agroprocessing sector, thus contributing to greater econonic diversification and increased urban and rural employment. This would be achieved by the project laying the groundwork for a strong supply response to the CFAF devaluation through the provision of: (a) increased access opportunities to local and regional markets; (b) increased exports, especially those of high value products; and (c) improved capabilities of the Regional Chambers of Agriculture and of subsectoral professional organizations to provide demand-driven support services to private entrepreneurs. The project would also reduce the incidence of poverty and enhance women's participation in and benefits from development, as most of the project's potential beneficiaries would be small entrepreneurs, many of them women, already involved in agricultural processing. Risks: The project's main risks are: (a) its reliance upon Chambers of Agriculture and professional organizations which are still weak and inexperienced; (b) poor management and misuse by the Agency of its autonomy in project implementation; and (c) the abandonment by Government of its present policy of support to the private sector. These risks constitute another set of reasons for the pilot format of this project. Precautions taken to minimize these risks include provisions for: (a) high selectivity in choosing organizations participating in implementation; (b) stringent management rules and procedures, especially with regard to sub- contracting procedures, similar to those already used successfully in the "AGETIPE" projects in the region; and (c) strong monitoring of

 STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT REPUBLIC OF MALI AGRICULTURAL TRADING AND PROCESSING PROMOTION PILOT PROJECT I. SECTOR BACKGROUND A. Overview 1.01 With a per capita GNP of only US$3 10 in 1992, Mali is one of the world's poorest countries. Per capita incomes declined between 1980 and 1991, as the 2.5 percent annual growth of real GDP lagged behind the 3.2% rate of population growth. Literacy (32%), life expectancy (45 years at birth), and access to health services are also among the lowest in the world. Mali's population, currently estimated at nine million, is mostly young and rural. Half of the population is under twenty years of age, and three fourths of them live in rural areas. Repeated droughts have increased migratory flows to urban centers, where the population is now growing at nearly 5 percent a year. 1.02 The rural sector dominates the Malian economy, accounting for 50 percent of GDP, occupying more than 80 percent of the active population, and providing 75 percent of export earnings. Of the country's 1.2 million square kilometers, only about one third is usable, with 24 percent taken up by pasture, 7 percent by forests, and only 2 percent by cultivation. Rain fed agriculture predominates, accounting for 90 percent of the 2.5 million hectares planted annually. The main crops, millet, sorghum and maize, are grown largely for home consumption. Other rain fed cash crops include cotton and groundnuts, cotton providing up to 45 percent of export revenues. Irrigated crops, covering about 160,000 hectares out of a potential 500,000 hectares, include sugarcane, vegetables, fruits, sorghum and wheat, with rice cultivation dominating by far. Livestock is the second most important export earner, accounting for 30 percent of export revenues. 1.03 Agroprocessing is by far the most important of the manufacturing subsectors. According to a 1988 census, agroprocessing enterprises constitute half the total number of formal manufacturing enterprises, and contribute 50 percent of gross production, 73 percent of value added, and 55 percent of employment in the formal manufacturing sector. These numbers do not include the few enterprises that specialize in exporting fruits and vegetables. Still, a considerable share of agricultural trading and processing is handled in the rural areas by small entrepreneurs in the informal sector, and particularly by women. These activities contribute more than two thirds of value added and employment in the informal sector. When informal artisanal activities are figured in, agroprocessing accounts for about 7 percent of GDP, and nearly 10 percent of employment.

Characteristics of Sector Enterprises 1.04 Agricultural trading and processing activities in Mali are carried out by a wide variety of enterprises, which can classified in four major categories: (a) a small group (15) of medium and large formal agroprocessing enterprises employing 10 or more persons; most of which were public enterprises undergoing rehabilitation programs, and which can now receive support from APEP and the IFC regional branches (APDF/AEF), and need not be supported by this project; (b) a limited number (10) of enterprises specialized in the export of fruits and vegetables; (c) a larger number (80) of small formal sector enterpises. mostly small, geographically dispersed rural entities using low productivity traditional technologies to produce low quality food and agro-industrial products destined for local consumption; and (d) thousands of small informal enterprises engaged in marketing and artisanal processing of agricultural products, mostly family part time enterprises using rudimentary techniques and little or no equipment. C. Recent Performances and Constraints to Sector Growth 1.05 Mali's performance in the areas of market gains for agro-processed products has not been satisfactory. The country has either lost or been unable to gain shares on regional or intemational markets for grains, meat, hides and skins, fruits and vegetables, and is far from fully exploiting its domestic market for these products. For example, Malian exports of mangoes plateau-ed from 1980 to 1990 at an average of 1,200 tons, losing European market shares (from 14 percent in 1985 to 6 percent in 1990) to some of its neighbors. According to BCEAO statistics, exports of hides and skins and of sheanuts are stagnant and extremely unstable. They have apparently ranged in the last two decades anywhere from 150 to 2,000 tons for hides and skins, and from 300 to 8,000 tons for shea nuts. On the domestic market, Mali has had trouble not only in diversifying production, but also in managing agricultural surpluses and their high seasonality, particularly for grain and horticultural products. Losses due to inadequate marketing, storage and handling range from 30 percent (onions) to 50 percent (mangoes). A wide range of processed products, cereals (particularly maize), dried fruits and vegetables, dried and smoked fish and meat, fruits, juices, jams and spices are being produced by small artisanal entrepreneurs who have difficulty gaining access to the markets, to appropriate technologies and/or to financing. 1.06 The relevant sector and project preparation work has identified key bottlenecks to the development of private agricultural marketing and processing enterprises:
 - 3 - (a) Limited access to information on market opportunities, fiscal and investment incentives, and export/import and transport regulations; (b) Limited know-how of post-harvest and marketing technologies and techniques; and weak and scattered support to private agroprocessing entrepreneurs; (c) Weak and limited number of professional associations; (d) Inadequate access to credit, particularly in rural areas; (e) Lack and/or low quality of rural infrastructure; and (f) Ineffective quality control for both exported and agroprocessed products. D. Sector Growth Persnectives 1.07 There is strong demand on European markets for many Malian agricultural products, such as mangoes and green beans. Potentially profitable market niches also exist for non-traditional products such as shea nuts, cashews, and gum resin. Mali's 1992 household consumption survey has also shown surprisingly high demand for fruits and vegetables, especially in urban areas. The high rate of urban population growth, and the anticipated improvements in per capita incomes, should greatly increase market demand for fresh fruits and vegetables, dairy products, and processed foods, as weil as for other agroindustrial products such as animal feed, soap, shoes, etc. Similar growth is expected in neighboring coastal countries, thus providing opportunities for increased regional exports of potatoes, onions, and livestock products. 1.08 These growth prospects have greatly improved since the recent CFAF devaluation. Livestock exports to the West African coastal countries have already rebounded, sales of cottonseed oil and other edible oils on regional export markets have expanded, and the outlook for import substitution for locally-processed cereals, fruits and vegetables, dairy products, cooking oil, shea nut soap, leather and textiles is promising. IL POLICY AND INSTITUTIONAL ENVIRONMENT A. Government Stratefv in the Rural Sector 2.01 Mali started a stabilization and structural adjustment program in 1982, but adjustment efforts did not become serious until 1988, when the Government began to implement a wide range of economic and institutional reforms. These reforms included domestic marketing and price liberalization, reform of the regulatory framework and tax regime, public enterprise restructuring and privatization, and the elimination of trade distortions. The civil service wage bill has been kept in check and the share of social program expenditures in the recurrent budget has been steadily increased. These measures have improved economic incentives and have allowed
 - 4 - market forces greater play in determining economic outcomes. In addition, the transparency and efficiency of public resource allocation have improved. Real GDP annual growth rates have jumped from less than 2 percent in the early 1980s to about 3.7 percent over the 1988-92 period. The overall fiscal deficit shrank from a high of 13.9 percent of GDP in 1985 to 7.7 percent in 1990. In 1993, however, the deficit rose again to 9.6 percent of GDP, and the balance of payments performance was adversely affected by the drop in world prices for cotton, the main export crop. 2.02 An important macroeconomic development has been the 50 percent devaluation of the CFA franc, decided in January 1994 by the Governments of the CFAF zone to which Mali belongs. This important decision should boost Mali's ongoing structural adjustment efforts and provide greater opportunities for economic growth. Already, livestock exports and prices have increased by more than 30 percent, cotton exports and revenues have doubled, and cotton production is expected to increase by about 50 percent in the next three years. A fourth PFP (1994-96) has been negotiated and agreed upon with the Government: it outlines a set of measures intended to accompany the devaluation to help restrain its inflationary impact and ensure that significant real depreciation is achieved. It also emphasizes the importance of continuing reform efforts, notably in agriculture, infrastructure, and public enterprise, as well as in the regulatory and incentive framework. As a result of effective implementation of most of the accompanying reforms, economic performance in 1994 has been impressive, with inflation holding steady at the projected rate of 35 percent, well below the 50 percent plus rates reached in some other CFAF countries, a 40 percent depreciation in the real exchange rate and substantial improvements in the fiscal deficit. Should such performance continue in the future, the improved competitiveness of agricultural and agro-processed products would be a lasting achievement. 2.03 Government has also redefined its agricultural development strategy in close collaboration with donors, including the Bank. A long-term Master Plan for Rural Development has been drawn up, along with a medium-term action plan aimed at refocusing the activities of the Ministry of Rural Development on public service functions, and on streamlining its institutions. The key objectives of the Government's agricultural development strategy are: (a) to further disengage Government from commercial activities and promote private sector initiative in such activities; (b) to provide adequate training for rural organizations which will be assigned lead roles in the identification and implementation of group activities; (c) to decentralize and streamline the administration to improve the effectiveness of local support services; and (d) to modernize Mali's low input/output agriculture through improved extension and agricultural research. In this context, the strategy consolidates the liberalization of agricultural markets, and limits the Government's role in marketing to that of manager of a food security stock. In the agroprocessing subsector, the Government's strategy focuses on four policy orientations: (a) financial rehabilitation, restructuring and/or privatization of public agroprocessing enterprises; (b) provision of incentives, via the investment code, in favor of rural-based enterprises; (c) support to the creation of active professional organizations; and (d) the improvement, through technical and institutional support, of the economics of agroprocessing in order to stimulate private investment in the subsector.
 B. Environment for Private Sector Development 2.04 Along with macroeconomic stabilization programs, the Government has put in place important regulatory, marketing and pricing policy reforms aimed at fostering private sector development, such as: (a) streamlining of regulations and administrative procedures, to make it easier for private entrepreneurs to engage in production and trade activities; (b) amendments to the labor code to facilitate hiring and dismissal; (c) elimination of price controls, except for petroleum products; (d) liberalization of trade policies, with the abolition of quantitative restrictions, the replacement of import licensing with a system of automatic registration, etc.; (e) reductions in the tax burden of formal sector enterprises; and (f) financial rehabilitation, restructuring, privatization, and/or liquidation of financially strained public enterprises, etc.. 2.05 Despite these reforms, numerous constraints to private sector development remain. First, Mali's financial and business laws and regulations, based generally on those of France, are too complex for Mali's still budding formal sector, making compliance time-consuming and costly, especially for small businesses. Second, the judicial system is isolated from the business community, lacks the appropriate specialized courts, and is thus unable to ensure the proper enforcement of business laws and regulations that is needed to secure private investments. Third, the complexity and diversity of taxes, and their high rate in some instances, are major impediments to private sector development. Fourth, customs fraud results not only in the loss of Government revenue, but also hinders the development of manufacturing activities, agroprocessing included. Fifth, the investment code is strongly biased towards large investments, and small enterprises are ill-informed and find it difficult to apply for and obtain the needed exemptions. C. Institutional Framework Government Institutions 2.06 Agricultural services have traditionally been rather weak, except in the CMDT and Office du Niger (ON) intervention areas. These two state enterprises have been relatively effective in providing technical support and in channeling financing to farmers. However, their ability to provide support to agricultural trading and processing enterprises is extremely limited, except in their respective areas of expertise, cotton and rice. 2.07 The Government, with the support of the IDA-financed Agricultural Services and National Agricultural Research projects, has recently embarked on a rehabilitation program of its research and extension services to cover areas outside CMDT and ON intervention. As a result,
 - 6 - IER and PNVA, the beneficiary institutions, have seen their capabilities to provide support enhanced, demand oriented and more effective. However, given the priorities accorded other agricultural subsectors, such as cereals and livestock, support capabilities in agricultural trading and processing have remained weak, and limited to attempts at improving traditional and low technology processes, such as drying of tomatoes and onions. Currently, training in post-harvest technologies is unavailable in Mali. 2.08 Government services in support of private business are weak. The "Office National de la Main d'Oeuvre et de l'Emploi" deals only with low-level skills. The "Centre d'Assistance aux Projets, Entreprises et Societes" has the capacity to provide training in management, accounting, and feasibility studies, but most of its efforts are currently geared towards recent secondary school and university graduates who lack business skills and experience. The IDA-financed Public Works Promotion Agency (AGETIPE) and Private Sector Promotion Agency (APEP) are active in Mali. But AGETIPE's support is too specialized, and the small informal agroprocessing enterprises, most of which are dispersed throughout rural Mali, have little or no access to APEP's support which is mostly geared towards large formal enterprises. Producer Organizations and Professional Associations 2.09 The Chamber of Agriculture of Mali (CAM), until recently under the strict control of the Ministry of Rural Development, has undergone major changes in status and structure. There are now eight Regional Chambers of Agriculture, composed of elected representatives of the rural population, and which have a broader mandate to promote private sector initiatives, to support professional organizations and producer interest groups, and to represent rural sector interests. Coordination of policy and programs, and support to the Regional Chambers is assured by the Permanent Assembly of the Malian Regional Chambers of Agriculture (APCAM). With training, technical support, and hands-on experience, the Regional Chambers of Agriculture should soon be able to play a leading role in providing various support services to private entrepreneurs in the agricultural and the agroprocessing sectors. 2.10 The Malian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (CCIM), although under the tutelage of the Ministry of Commerce, is supposed to represent the interests of trade, industry, handicrafts, and service enterprises vis-a-vis the Government, to provide technical and market information to these enterprises, and to advise the Government on policies and regulations affecting businesses. However, being essentially a state-controlled entity, and lacking the needed personnel, data, documentation and access to information, the Chamber has shown little effectiveness in providing support to business. The IDA-financed Private Sector Support Project will provide support for the restructuring of the CCIM. 2.11 There are also some specialized professional associations involved with the agricultural trading and processing subsectors. The "Reseau des Entreprises du Mali" is a member of the "Reseau des Entreprises de l'Afrique de l'Ouest", which aims to develop private business in West Africa by identifying the needs of the African private sector, lobbying to change the regulatory framework, and promoting trade throughout the region. AMELEF was created by the leading exporters to promote the professional and economic interests of fruits and vegetables exporters. A cotton producers union, SYCOV, has already played a key role in negotiating producer prices with CMDT. The Mutual Association of Hides and Leather (MPCP), the
 - 7 - Butchers Cooperative, and the Association of Livestock Traders are active in the livestock subsector. 2.12 Producers' organizations designed for input provision and/or product marketing, such as cooperatives, pre-cooperatives and other "groupements", proliferated until the mid- 1980s, their creation most often initiated by Government agencies and their operations supported by the administration and/or by development projects. However, as part of its disengagement policy, the Government has stepped back from direct interference and allowed them a high degree of autonomy. With the decrease in Governmental support and subsidies, many have stopped operations. Malian legislation has also recently provided for the creation of economically and commercially-oriented organizations called "Groupements d'Interet Economique" (GIE), usually involving fewer than ten members who pool their resources for development activities, and who are jointly responsible for the repayment of credit. Unlike most of the traditional "Tons Villageois" and "Associations Villageoises" (AV), which usually have community-based and socially-oriented activities, cooperatives and GIEs can play a key role in providing extension services, input supply, product marketing, and access to and reimbursement of credit. Other National and International Support Organizations 2.13 It is estimated that about 200 non-governmental organizations (NGOs) operate in Mali. Only a few are specialized in supporting agroprocessing activities. NGOs often depend on fluctuating financial assistance from the donor community, and their programs, usually of limited scope, are often relatively uncoordinated with each other. However, their closeness to beneficiaries and their reliance on strong beneficiary participation are positive factors that make NGOs key partners in any decentralized development activity. CMDT, for example, is relying to an increasing degree on contractual arrangements with NGOs for the implementation of specific activities in its area of influence. 2.14 CECI is a Canadian NGO, funded by the Canadian Agency for International Development, which specializes in providing technical assistance to small agroprocessing activities in developing countries. It has extensive experience in promoting appropriate food drying technologies (meat, fish, fruits and vegetables) and cereals processing in Mali, with projects in the Mopti and Kayes regions, in Burkina Faso, and in other neighboring countries. The FED/PME/PMI is a European Development Fund financed project which provides financing to small and medium size enterprises, through regional agencies recently transformed into decentralized financial institutions called "Credit Initiative". "PAPME Canada" is a similar project now being completed, with funding available for another year but restricted to provision of technical assistance to private entrepreneurs in their marketing activities. The "Programme pour la Valorisation des Cereales Locales dans le Sahel (PROCELOS), a 'Comite Inter-Etats de Lutte contre la Secheresse ans le Sahel (CILSS) program active in Burkina Faso, Mali and Senegal, is promoting the processing of local grains. Support is provided to small and medium enterprises via local consulting firms and consists of the provision of technical and market information, local market promotion for specific products, and individual counseling on technical and managerial matters. 2.15 The Liaison Committee for Europe, Africa and the Caribbean (COLEACP), an international organization supported partially by the European Development Fund, is active in
 promoting trade in tropical fruits, off-season vegetables, ornamental plants, and flowers and spices. In addition to its traditional functions of disseminating market information and providing training and technical expertise in export promotion, it is currently coordinating a Sahel-wide effort to import the export business and enhance coordination of export policies and programs. D. Financial Intermediation and Access to Credit 2.16 Farmers and agroprocessing entrepreneurs have limited access to credit to finance productive medium and long term investments. Agricultural credit accounts for a small share of total credit to the economy, and the bulk of extended credit is for short-term financing of less than two years. In 1991, the ratio of agricultural to total credit was 39 percent for short-term loans, and only 2 percent for long and medium term loans. Within the agricultural portfolio, 98 percent of loans are seasonal short-term credits that finance farm inputs and crop marketing. Rural development agencies and projects, especially CMDT and Office du Niger, play a prominent intermediary role in formal credit allocation and management, channeling about 90 percent of all agricultural credit. 2.17 Until recently, banks have operated under financial policies that discouraged lending to private operators. They have been even more reluctant to lend to small formal and informal enterprises, which are characterized by a limited knowledge of markets and marketing skills, of technical processes, and by very weak capabilities in the design and presentation of investment projects. Unwillingness of banks to provide investment lending is also due to their own weaknesses, limited contact and knowledge of small rural entrepreneurs, their limited experience in lending to them, and weak capabilities in appraising the financial viability and risks of agroprocessing activities. 2.18 Within the context of the recent liberalization of financial markets, a money market was introduced by BCEAO that pays the prevailing rate of interest (8 percent to 9 percent) only on that portion of offered funds for which there is a solvent demand. As this proportion has fallen to less than 50 percent of banks' deposits with BCEAO, banks now have a growing incentive to use their excess liquidity for lending to the private sector. Also, the savings and loan cooperatives, which traditionally recycled their excess resources with the banks, will now be more inclined to extend medium- and long-term credit. An increased dialogue between businesses and financial institutions, promoted by this pilot project, will result in the design of risk-reducing programs and mechanisms that will likely increase the availability of investment lending to private enterprises, and increase the access to long- and medium-term credit of agroprocessing firms. m. IDA STRATEGY A. Country Assistance Strateev 3.01 The Bank's strategy for Mali's rural sector is consistent with Government policy orientations and includes the following objectives: (a) to improve the enabling environment
 -9- needed to enhance business opportunities for the private sector and encourage disengagement of the State from commercial activities; (b) to improve technical support to producers through more effective research and extension, in order to boost and diversify production as well as to improve the international competitiveness of Malian exports; (c) to enhance training for, and promote active participation of, rural groups in the design and implementation of rural development activities; (d) to promote private investment in irrigation and the selective rehabilitation of existing schemes rather than the construction of new ones; (e) to promote private investment in agricultural trading and processing; (f) to support a comprehensive natural resource management program and the creation of a legal and institutional framework giving local communities more authority and accountability in its implementation, as well as reforms aimed at intensifying production through appropriate land use policies; and (g) to improve infrastructure and transport. B. IDA Portfolio 3.02 IDA's portfolio in the Malian rural sector has closely matched the above strategy. Lessons from Past Lending Experiences 3.05 Lessons from the Bank's lending experience in agriculture suggest, first, that farmers and agroprocessing entrepreneurs are responsive to improved and profitable technologies, and are prepared to invest time and resources to adopt them. One can cite the example of rice transplantation techniques and the use of organic manure, which have been adopted on an impressive scale over the last few years. Second, individual farmers or groups are able and willing to play important roles in designing and managing rural development activities. Over the last few years, private small-scale irrigation schemes have proliferated despite the lack of Government support. Under PDCL's natural resource management operations, producer groups have also shown increasing enthusiasm and willingness to take important initiatives in implementing project activities. Third, centralized project management by the Government tends to lose sight of farmers' constraints and priorities. Results from the Mopti Area Development Project clearly indicate that the project's centralized management unit, in addition to being ill-placed to react to complex local conditions, was handicapped by inefficient administrative procedures as well as by weak management, and that the local communities and private sector entities were insufficiently involved in project planning and implementation. Thus, there is a need to tap the management skills of professionally oriented and decentralized institutions to coordinate and implement Government-financed operations in the rural sector. This "private provision of public services" approach, received favorably by Government, as illustrated by the AGETIPE and Private Sector Promotion projects, will be used for the proposed project. 3.06 IDA's experience with projects channeling support to small agricultural trading and processing enterprises through professional organizations is rather recent, hence the pilot format of this project. Proiect Benefits 6.01 Main project benefits would be higher growth rates in the agricultural trading and agroprocessing sector, thus contributing to greater economic diversification and increased urban and rural employment. doc.repnme: Mali - Agricultural Trading and Processing Promotion Pilot Project
doc.abstracts: The Agricultural Trading and Processing Promotion Pilot project is a five year project that will address key sectoral constraints to private investment in agricultural processing and marketing, and will focus primarily on capacity-building and on the transfer of know-how to the private sector through information networks, training, specialized technical assistance, and study tours. The project will pursue a two pronged approach: (a) provision of generic support in three regions to all profitable agroprocessing private entrepreneurs, upstream and downstream of agricultural production, and (b) transfer of specialized expertise to enterprises operating in subsectors or product lines with a high potential for international export which require high-quality standards, such as fresh and dried fruits and vegetables, hides and skins, and shea nuts and other exotic products. Project management will be entrusted to an "Agricultural Trading and Processing Promotion Agency". The Government will exercise overall project supervision through the Ministry of Rural Development and Environment. The Agency will have streamlined operating structures, comprising a coordinating unit located in Bamako, and, in full operation, three regional support units. The project will provide funding for: (i) the operating of the Agency's three regional branches in the Sikasso, Segou, and Mopti regions; (ii) support packages, including specialized technical assistance, training, studies and investment funds for three professional organizations promoting vertical integration for the fruit/vegetable, hide/skins, and oilseeds/shea nut subsectors; (iii) the Agency's operations and management, and the establishment and operation of an agricultural processing and marketing information exchange network; and (iv) activities aimed at facilitating entrepreneurs' access to investment financing and credit.
